definitions.definition: produce or provide (a natural, agricultural, or industrial product).
examples: the land yields grapes and tobacco

definitions.definition: (of an action or process) produce or deliver (a result or gain).
examples: this method yields the same results
synonyms: pay out; informalrake in "too many projects yield poor returns"

definitions.definition: (of a financial or commercial process or transaction) generate (a specified financial return).
examples: such investments yield direct cash returns

definitions.definition: give way to arguments, demands, or pressure.
examples: the Western powers now yielded when they should have resisted
synonyms: raise/show the white flag; Moreinformalthrow in the towel
cave in "the duke was forced to yield"give in to
allow; informalcave in to; formalaccede to "he yielded to her demands"

examples: they might yield up their secrets
synonyms: leave "the nobility yielded power to the capitalists"

definitions.definition: (especially in a legislature) allow another the right to speak in a debate.
examples: I yield to the gentleman from Kentucky

definitions.definition: give right of way to other traffic.
(of a mass or structure) give way under force or pressure.
examples: he reeled into the house as the door yielded

definitions.definition: the full amount of an agricultural or industrial product.
the amount of money brought in, e.g., interest from an investment or revenue from a tax; return.
examples: an annual dividend yield of 20 percent
synonyms: earnings "risky investments usually have higher yields"

definitions.definition: the amount obtained from a process or reaction relative to the theoretical maximum amount obtainable.
(of a nuclear weapon) the force in tons or kilotons of TNT required to produce an equivalent explosion.
examples: yields ranging from five kilotons to 100 tons
